subsection.title: Examples
subsection.p:
Here are some basic problem types about histograms.
The base of a block in a histogram sits on the interval from 15 to 40 in the horizontal axis, and has height 2.3. How much data lies in the range from 15 to 40?
The base of a block in a histogram sits on the interval from 15 to 40 in the horizontal axis, and has height 2.3, and the data is evenly spread within the block. How much data lies in the range from 15 to 20?
26 percent of data values in a data set called X lie in the range 34.7 to 40.8. What is the height of the block in a histogram for X whose base sits on the interval from 34.7 to 40.8?
The solutions use the equation \text{ area } = \text{ (base)(height)} and the fact that the area of a block in a histogram is the percent of data in the range along the base of the block. Here are the solutions.
\text{ area } \amp = \text{ (base)(height)} \amp = (40-15)(2.3) \amp = 57.5\%
\text{ area } \amp = \text{ (base)(height)} \amp = (20-15)(2.3) \amp = 11.5\%
\text{ height } \amp = \frac{\text{area}}{\text{base}} \amp = \frac{26}{40.8-34.7} \amp \approx 4.26\text{ percent per unit}

subsection.title: Examples
subsection.p:
Here are some basic problem types about the normal curve. Data called X is approximately normally distributed, with \AVE(X)=72.3 and \SD(X)=6.7.
(symmetric region) Estimate the percent of data in the range 72.3\pm 3.9.
(asymmetric region) Estimate the percent of data in the range 69.0 to 81.0.
(left tail region) Estimate the percentile rank for the data values 69.0 and 81.0.
(from area to z) Estimate the data values with 70th and 35th percentile ranks.
Here are the solutions. Here are the drawing method solution steps taught in the textbook.
The z values for 72.3\pm 3.9 are \pm \frac{3.9}{6.7} \approx \pm .58. The normal table shows that the area between these z values is about 44\%.
The z value for 69.0 is z_L=\frac{69.0-72.3}{6.7}\approx -.49, and the z value for 81.0 is z_R = \frac{81.0-72.3}{6.7}\approx 1.30. The corresponding areas in the normal table are 38\% and 81\%, respectively. The area from z_L to 0 is about 38/2=19\% and the area from 0 to z_R is about 81/2=40.5\%, so the area from z_L to z_R is about 19+40.5=59.5\%\approx 60\%.
We have the same values z_L,z_R from the previous part. First, we consider z_L=-.49. Start with the observation that 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }-.49) \amp + (\text{area between }-.49 \text{ and }+.49) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }+4.9).
By mirror symmetry, we have (\text{area to the left of }-.49) = (\text{area to the right of }+4.9). Putting these together, we get (\text{area to the left of }-.49)= \frac{100\%-(\text{area between }-.49 \text{ and }+.49)}{2} which is (100 -38)/2=31\%. Next, we consider z_R=1.30. Start with (\text{area to the left of }1.30)\amp = (\text{area left of }0) \amp + (\text{area between }0 \text{ and }1.30) \amp = 50\% + 81/2 \amp \approx 90\%.
First, we find the z value that has 70th percentile rank. Let's call that value A. Starting with the observation that 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }A) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }A) \amp = 70 + (\text{area to the right of }A)
we conclude that the area to the right of A is 30\%. By mirror symmetry, it must be that the area to the left of -A is also 30\%, so the area between -A and +A must be 100 - 2(30) = 40\%. Using the normal curve table, we find that A\approx .52. This converts to an X value of X=(.52)(6.7)+72.3\approx 75.8. Next, we find a z value that has 35th percentile rank. Let's call that value -B (so that -B is to the left of average, and +B is to the right of average). Starting with 100\% \amp = (\text{area to the left of }-B) \amp + (\text{area between }-B \text{ and }B) \amp + (\text{area to the right of }B)
By mirror symmetry, we have (\text{area to the left of }-B) = (\text{area to the right of }B). It follows that both sides of this equation are 35\%, so we conclude that (\text{area between }-B \text{ and }B)= 100 - 2(35)=30\%. From the normal table, we get -B\approx -.385. This converts to an X value of X=(-.385)(6.7)+72.3\approx 69.7.

subsection.title: Examples
subsection.p:
Here are some basic problem types about regression.
(Ch 10) The scatter diagram for data called X,Y shows a linear association, with the following summary statistics.
\AVE(X)\amp =20.13 \amp \amp \amp \AVE(Y)\amp =15.86 \SD(X)\amp =3.65 \amp \amp \amp \SD(Y)\amp =4.90 \amp \amp r\amp=.82 \amp \amp
Estimate the average Y value for data whose X value is near 24.8.
Estimate the average X value for data whose Y value is near 21.0.
(Ch 11) Continuing the previous problem, suppose now that the Y data is normally distributed within each thin vertical strip, and that the scatter diagram is homoscedastic. For data whose X value is near 24.8, estimate the percent of Y data in the range 15.86 and higher.
(Ch 10) Suppose that data called V,W have a linear association with a correlation of r=.65, and that V,W are both approximately normally distributed. Estimate the average percentile rank for W data whose V value is close to 80th percentile.

Here are the solutions. Here are the drawing method solution steps taught in the textbook.
Use the facts that the regression line passes close to vertical centers of thin vertical strips, that the regression line passes through the point of averages (\AVE(X),\AVE(Y)), and has slope equal to r\frac{\SD(Y)}{\SD(X)}. Let (A,B)=(\AVE(X),\AVE(Y)) be the point of averages and let (P,Q) be the point on the regression line with P=24.8, so that Q is the Y-coordinate we are looking for. The run is P-A=4.67, the rise is \text{(slope)(run)}=.82\frac{4.90}{3.65}(4.67)\approx 5.137, and Q=\text{rise } + B \approx 21.0.
We switch the horizontal and vertical roles of X and Y so that we can find the desired X value as the center of a thin vertical strip. Use the point of averages (\AVE(Y),\AVE(X)) and the slope r\frac{\SD(X)}{\SD(Y)}\approx .611. The run is 21.0-15.86= 5.14, the rise is \text{(slope)(run)} =(.611)(5.14)\approx 3.14 , and the desired prediction is 20.13+3.14= 23.27.
This question is about the Y data in the thin vertical strip that corresponds to X=24.8. Let's call this data U. From the previous problem, we have the estimate \AVE(U)=21.0. From the assumption of homoscedasticity, the rms error 4.90\sqrt{1-.82^2}\approx 2.80 for the regression line is a good estimate for \SD(U). Using the fact that U is normally distributed, we are looking for the area under a normal curve that lies to the right of z=\frac{15.86-21.0}{2.80}\approx -1.83. The normal table value for z=1.83 is about 93\%, so the area to the right of z=-1.83 is about 50+93/2\approx 96.5\% or about 97\%.
First, find the z value for the 80th percentile of the normal data V. Let's call this value A. There is 20\% of the V data to the right of A, so there is 100-2(20)=60\% of the V data between -A and +A. The normal table gives A\approx .84, so the horizontal run from \AVE(V) to the 80th percentile V value is .84 standard units for V. The vertical rise along the regression line is r(.84)=0.65(.84)\approx .55 standard units for W. Now convert the z value .55 to percentile. The normal table shows that the area between -.55 and +.55 is about 42\%, so the area to the left of .55 is about 50+42/2\approx 71\%.

Use the definitions of independent and dependent events given in to answer the following questions.
(Ch 13) Are events E,F independent or dependent in Game 1? In Game 2? Explain.
(Ch 13) Are events E,G independent or dependent in Game 1? In Game 2? Explain.
(Ch 15) Are events G,H independent or dependent in Game 1? In Game 2? Explain.

ol.li: In Game 1, we have P(F)=1/7=P(F|E), so E,F are independent. In Game 2, we have P(F)=1/7\neq 1/6=P(F|E), so E,F are dependent.

In Game 1, we have P(G)=4/49, while P(G|E)=2/7. Since P(G)\neq P(G|E), we conclude that E,G are dependent in Game 1. In Game 2, we have P(G)=2/42, while P(G|E)=1/6. Since P(G)\neq P(G|E), we conclude that E,G are dependent in Game 2.

In Game 1, we have P(H)={7\choose 2} (2/7)^2 (5/7)^5\approx 31.87\%, while P(H|G)=P(G)\cdot P(\text{no vowels in 5 draws}) = (2/7)^2(5/7)^5\approx 1.52\% \lt P(H). Since P(H)\neq P(H|G), we conclude that G,H are dependent in Game 1. In Game 2, we have P(H)=100\% =P(H|G). We conclude that G,H are independent in Game 2.

introduction.p: Problems 110 below are about the following game. A fair die is rolled 600 times. On each roll, you win $4 if you get a 6. You lose $1 if you get something different from a 6.

exercise.p: The total winnings will be about $ give or take $ or so.

answer.p:
The box model has six tickets: (1) 4 and (5) -1's.
\AVE(\text{box}) \amp = -1/6 \SD(\text{box}) \amp = 5\sqrt{\frac{1}{6}\cdot \frac{5}{6}} \approx 1.86 \text{expected(sum) }\amp = -100 \text{SE(sum) } \amp \approx 45.64

One possible box model has (3) 1's and (3) 0's. A simpler box model has (1) 1 and (1) 0 with equal probabilities of 1/2 each.
\AVE(\text{box}) \amp = 1/2 \SD(\text{box})\amp = 1/2 \text{expected(sum) } \amp = 300 \text{SE(sum) } \amp \approx 12.25

exercise.p: The chance that the number of even rolls will be off by 20 or more from the expected number is about .

On every 6th roll (that is, on roll numbers 6, 12, 18, etc) you win a blue marble if exactly half of the last 6 rolls came up even. The chance that you win 35 or more blue marbles in 600 rolls is . Use the continuity correction to be as precise as possible.

answer.p: The probability of exactly 3 evens in 6 rolls is {6 \choose 3}\left(\frac{1}{2}\right)^6 = 31.25\% (using the binomial probability formula). A box model has 3125 1's and 6875 0's, with 100 draws. The average of the box is .3125 and the SD of the box is \sqrt{.3125\cdot .6875} \approx .464. The expected sum is 31.25 and the SE for the sum is 4.64. The z value for 35 blues is z = \frac{34.5-31.25}{4.64}\approx .70. The normal curve table has an area of about 52\% for z=.70, so the probability is about (100-52)/2=24\% (if you do not use the continuity correction, you get z=.81 and a probability of about 21\%).
